papers.abstract: Survival analysis is an important tool for modeling time-to-event data, e.g., to predict the survival time of a patient after a cancer diagnosis or a certain treatment. While deep neural networks work well in standard prediction tasks, it is still unclear how to best utilize these deep models in survival analysis due to the difficulty of modeling right censored data, especially for multi-omics data. Although existing methods have shown the advantage of multi-omics integration in survival prediction, it remains challenging to extract complementary information from different omics and improve the prediction accuracy. In this work, we propose a novel multi-omics deep survival prediction approach by dually fused graph convolutional network (GCN) named FGCNSurv. Our FGCNSurv is a complete generative model from multi-omics data to survival outcome of patients, including feature fusion by a factorized bilinear model, graph fusion of multiple graphs, higher-level feature extraction by GCN, and survival prediction by a Cox proportional hazard model. The factorized bilinear model enables to capture cross-omics features and quantify complex relations from multi-omics data. By fusing single-omics features and the cross-omics features, and simultaneously fusing multiple graphs from different omics, GCN with the generated dually fused graph could capture higher-level features for computing the survival loss in the Cox-PH model. Comprehensive experimental results on real-world datasets with gene expression and microRNA expression data show that the proposed FGCNSurv method outperforms existing survival prediction methods, and imply its ability to extract complementary information for survival prediction from multi-omics data.

events.Text: Survival analysis is an important tool for modeling time-to-event data, e.g., to predict the survival time of a patient after a cancer diagnosis or a certain treatment. While deep neural networks work well in standard prediction tasks, it is still unclear how to best utilize these deep models in survival analysis due to the difficulty of modeling right censored data, especially for multi-omics data. Although existing methods have shown the advantage of multi-omics integration in survival prediction, it remains challenging to extract complementary information from different omics and improve the prediction accuracy.
events.Main Action: Despite significant advancements in deep learning technology...

Agent: researchers in the domain of machine learning and survival analysis

Primary Object: integrate multi-omics data to enhance survival prediction models
Secondary Object: address the technical challenges associated with right-censored data

Context: While deep neural networks excel in standard prediction tasks, their application in survival analysis faces complexities due to the nature of right-censored data
Purpose: To develop effective methodologies for utilizing deep learning models in survival analysis by overcoming challenges posed by multi-omics data
Method: Deep neural networks integrated with traditional statistical methods tailored for analyzing high-dimensional genomic data
Results: Improved prediction accuracy demonstrated compared to conventional approaches in several benchmark studies
Analysis: Identified inherent limitations in current deep learning implementations when dealing with censored survival data
Challenge: Extracting meaningful insights from diverse omics datasets amidst incomplete temporal information
Ethical: Potential biases introduced by dataset selection may affect generalizability of predictive models
Implications: Advances in methodology could lead to personalized treatment plans informed by longitudinal molecular profiling
Contradictions: Findings suggest that while deep learning shows promise, specialized adaptations are needed for survival analysis contexts

events.Text: In this work, we propose a novel multi-omics deep survival prediction approach by dually fused graph convolutional network (GCN) named FGCNSurv. Our FGCNSurv is a complete generative model from multi-omics data to survival outcome of patients, including feature fusion by a factorized bilinear model, graph fusion of multiple graphs, higher-level feature extraction by GCN, and survival prediction by a Cox proportional hazard model. The factorized bilinear model enables to capture cross-omics features and quantify complex relations from multi-omics data. By fusing single-omics features and the cross-omics features, and simultaneously fusing multiple graphs from different omics, GCN with the generated dually fused graph could capture higher-level features for computing the survival loss in the Cox-PH model.

Context: Handling high-dimensional biological data types and integrating diverse genomic structures
Purpose: accurately predict survival outcomes tailored to individual patients to enhance personalized treatment plans
Method: survival prediction by a Cox proportional hazard model
Results: experiments demonstrate improved accuracy compared to current methods

events.Text: Comprehensive experimental results on real-world datasets with gene expression and microRNA expression data show that the proposed FGCNSurv method outperforms existing survival prediction methods, and imply its ability to extract complementary information for survival prediction from multi-omics data.

Agent: Comprehensive experimental results on real-world datasets

Primary Object: gene expression and microRNA expression data

Context: with gene expression and microRNA expression data
Purpose: to evaluate the proposed FGCNSurv method against existing survival prediction methods
Method: applying deep learning models across multi-omics data
Results: the proposed FGCNSurv method outperforms existing survival prediction methods
imply its ability to extract complementary information for survival prediction from multi-omics data
Analysis: results demonstrate the effectiveness of integrating diverse omics data for accurate survival predictions
Implications: suggesting broad applicability in personalized treatment plans and understanding disease progression mechanisms

papers.abstract: In functional imaging studies, accurately synchronizing the time course of experimental manipulations and stimulus presentations with resulting imaging data is crucial for analysis. Current software tools lack such functionality, requiring manual processing of the experimental and imaging data, which is error-prone and potentially non-reproducible. We present VoDEx, an open-source Python library that streamlines the data management and analysis of functional imaging data. VoDEx synchronizes the experimental timeline and events (e.g., presented stimuli, recorded behavior) with imaging data. VoDEx provides tools for logging and storing the timeline annotation, and enables retrieval of imaging data based on specific time-based and manipulation-based experimental conditions.

events.Text: In functional imaging studies, accurately synchronizing the time course of experimental manipulations and stimulus presentations with resulting imaging data is crucial for analysis. Current software tools lack such functionality, requiring manual processing of the experimental and imaging data, which is error-prone and potentially non-reproducible.

We present VoDEx, an open-source Python library that streamlines the data management and analysis of functional imaging data. VoDEx synchronizes the experimental timeline and events (e.g., presented stimuli, recorded behavior) with imaging data. VoDEx provides tools for logging and storing the timeline annotation, and enables retrieval of imaging data based on specific time-based and manipulation-based experimental conditions.

Context: by synchronizing the experimental timeline and events
Purpose: to provide an efficient way to handle complex data management tasks
Method: providing tools for logging and retrieval functions
Results: enabling researchers to retrieve imaging data efficiently
Analysis: highlighted the effectiveness of their approach compared to traditional methods
Challenge: emphasized the difficulty in coordinating temporal aspects of experiments
Ethical: no direct discussion of ethical implications
Implications: opens new avenues for advancing neuroimaging technologies and practices
